title: Check the file system requirements
content:
Role Location Privileges required
System administrator All nodes Root or sudo

The following sections are a conceptual overview of the directory structure and sizing requirements of OMT to help you set up a server or a virtual machine (VM) for the installation.

In this topic, the definition of 1 GB is 1024 x 1024 x 1024 bytes.

Directory structure 

All Linux systems use space under the root filesystem (“/”). It's possible to assign enough space under one root partition to contain most of the directories used by OMT. However, a best practice is to set up a few separate volumes or filesystems for directory trees such as /tmp or /var. You may follow your own system administration best practices to assign filesystems, as long as they have enough space in the directories specified below. One exception is the local Persistent Volumes that are required on OMT worker nodes in production deployments, as discussed below. 

/ (root filesystem)

This is the root directory, which is used for various Linux operating system functions. The minimum recommended size for this directory is 10 GB on all nodes, assuming that all the subdirectories are in other filesystem partitions.

/var

This is the directory where the system logs are located. If the /var directory and root filesystem (/) aren't on the same file system, the minimum recommended size for this directory is 10 GB on all nodes.

/tmp

This directory is used by the operating system as a temporary location and is used for some application files. The minimum recommended size for this directory is 10 GB on all your systems. In the install.properties setup file, it's possible to specify an alternative location for temporary installation files (TMP_FOLDER), which would reduce this requirement if for some reason /tmp must be smaller.

Directory to contain the downloaded images

The installation process requires you to download the OMT and application images to the first control plane node or download them on a separate system and copy them to the first control plane node. You can specify a directory for the downloaded images or use the default directory (/var/opt/cdf/offline). The image processing done by the uploadimages.sh script requires free space in the target directory that equals up to twice the size of the images. This space is required only temporarily on the first control plane node, and isn't needed on any other node. You can remove the images once the installation is complete. 

Home and OMT runtime directories

These can be in any location of your choice, but by default they're both under /opt (/opt/cdf and /opt/cdf/data). If you choose to install into a different home location or change the runtime directory location, then you need to edit the corresponding CDF_HOME and the RUNTIME_CDFDATA_HOME parameters in the install.properties file to point to the directories you wish to use. You can configure those parameters along with others while completing the preparation tasks. However, we recommend that you leave these as the default. 

The largest potential contributor to the space requirements of the OMT runtime directory is the /opt/cdf/data directory. Note that the filesystem hosting the /opt/cdf/data directory (the directory can be customized) must be an xfs filesystem with ftype=1 (1 is the default ftype for xfs), or ext4.

Sizing

Server sizing for control plane and worker nodes

These sizing recommendations apply to OMT only. If you want to create a single node deployment for a non-production environment with the NFS volumes also exported on this node, the minimum memory for the node is 20 GB.

The following sizing recommendations apply to control plane nodes only. For the recommended space on worker nodes, refer to the application documentation.

Database sizing

On your external database systems, follow the database specific documentation and guidelines for filesystem allocation. In general, most databases allow you to specify the directories you wish to contain the database catalog and data. The required capacity of your database systems will vary depending on load and retention policies.
